awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CNS Core: Small: Intermittent and Incremental Inference with Statistical Neural Network for Energy-Harvesting Powered Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
The maturation of energy-harvesting (EH) technology and the recent emergence of viable intermittent computing, which stores harvested energy in an energy storage and supports an episode of program execution, creates the opportunity to build sophisticated batteryless computing systems. This project aims to realize artificial intelligence (AI) in such batteryless devices. However, there are two main challenges: 1. most existing Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) are hard to fit in resource-constrained microcontrollers. 2. DNNs usually require multiple execution episodes to obtain one inference result and it may take indefinite amount of time due to the weak and unpredictable harvested power. To address these challenges, this project is developing multi-exit DNNs, which can output incrementally accurate inference results during each execution episode. Three tasks will be carried out to lay the technological foundation for intermittent incremental inference on EH-powered IoT devices. First, novel power trace aware compression, online pruning and adaptation algorithms will be developed to ensure efficient deployment of multi-exit DNNs on intermittently-powered devices. Second, new multi-exit statistical and incremental neural networks (MESI-NN) will be developed to further reduce the latency and improve the accuracy and energy efficiency. Third, new neural architecture search algorithms will be developed to automatically search the best MESI-NN architecture. This project will be evaluated with real system and applications such as image classification, keyword spotting, and activity recognition. 

Realizing AI in EH-powered batteryless devices can enable persistent, event-driven sensing capabilities in which the main device (e.g. a battery-draining camera) can remain off until awaken by the EH-powered device when it detects events of interest. The societal impact of the proposed research is to significantly extend the lifetime of sensors and devices deployed in remote areas, which will drastically benefit various consumer, business, scientific and national security applications. This project will expose students to related cutting-edge knowledge and hands-on research opportunities and elevate their competence and confidence in facing of today's highly competitive global job market. The education impact of the proposed research includes the integration of various education activities based on the resources available to the two PIs such as DAC System Design Contest; outreach for local K-12 students through Pitt’s Investing Now summer school and ND’s CS curriculum for K-12 students in Indiana; undergraduate research with emphasis on minority participation, and course integration of the research outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The growing demand for intelligent computing in everyday applications has driven the need for devices that can function efficiently without traditional battery power. This project aimed to bring artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities to energy-harvesting (EH) batteryless devices, which collect and store energy from their surroundings, such as solar panels or radio waves. By enabling AI in these devices, we can significantly expand their potential for long-term use in remote environments, smart homes, healthcare, and security applications.

Key Findings and Achievements

Development of Multi-Exit Deep Neural Networks (DNNs): Traditional AI models require continuous power to process information, but EH-powered devices operate with intermittent energy. To address this, we developed multi-exit DNNs, which allow a device to produce increasingly accurate results in each power cycle. This means that even with an unstable power supply, the device can still generate useful outputs rather than having to restart the computation each time power is lost.

Efficient AI Deployment in Resource-Constrained Devices: To ensure AI models fit within the limited memory and processing power of EH-powered devices, we created power-aware compression, online pruning, and adaptation techniques. These methods allow the models to dynamically adjust based on available energy, optimizing both performance and efficiency.

Incremental and Statistical Neural Networks: We introduced Multi-Exit Statistical and Incremental Neural Networks (MESI-NN) to improve the speed, accuracy, and energy efficiency of AI models. This innovation enables devices to make early predictions with lower power requirements and refine their outputs as more energy becomes available.

Automated Neural Architecture Search (NAS): To find the most efficient AI models for EH-powered devices, we developed new NAS algorithms that automatically optimize AI architectures for different energy constraints and application needs.

Broader Impacts and Societal Benefits

The outcomes of this project have far-reaching benefits for society, particularly in areas where long-term, battery-free sensing is critical:

Extended Sensor Lifetimes: The ability to run AI on EH-powered devices significantly reduces reliance on batteries, allowing sensors deployed in remote or hazardous locations to operate indefinitely. This can benefit environmental monitoring, disaster response, and scientific research.

Event-Driven Smart Systems: By incorporating AI, these devices can detect and respond to important events. For example, a batteryless motion sensor can activate a camera only when necessary, preserving energy in security and surveillance applications.

Education and Workforce Development: This project provided hands-on research opportunities for students, including underrepresented minorities, through undergraduate research programs and outreach activities. Educational initiatives such as the IEEE/ACM DAC System Design Contest and IEEE/ACM ICCAD TinyML Design Contest, both of which initiated by the PI, helped inspire and train the next generation of AI and embedded systems researchers.

This research has laid the foundation for bringing AI capabilities to batteryless, energy-harvesting devices, paving the way for more sustainable and intelligent sensing solutions. The technological advancements in power-efficient AI models, multi-exit DNNs, and automated architecture search have the potential to transform a wide range of industries, from healthcare to national security. The societal and educational impacts of this work ensure that both current and future generations can contribute to the ongoing evolution of smart, energy-efficient technology.
